Born in Venice, he studied art with his father, famed Rococco artist Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, and by age 20 was accepting his own commissions. As he moved from Wurzburg to Vicenza to Madrid, his style evolved, and while he retained the decorative technique of his father he gradually incorporated a more mature, realistic approach into his paintings. Representative of his early work is the 1750 painting Scène Carnival, or, Le menuet, which combines his father's ornate, brightly colored Rococco influence with the realistic scene of performers dancing at a carnival. Originally attributed to his father, the painting was part of the collection of the Venetian polymath, Count Francesco Algarotti, and  is currently in the Louvre.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="545" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Giacomo  Leonardis was an Italian engraver. Born in Palmanova, Venice Republic, he studied under Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, and made popular etchings of Italian paintings.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="0"><subfield code="a">Dance</subfield><subfield code="v">Early works to 1800</subfield><subfield code="v">Pictorial works.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="0"><subfield code="a">Carnivals</subfield><subfield code="v">Early works to 1800</subfield><subfield code="v">Pictorial works.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="655" ind1=" " ind2="7"><subfield code="a">Prints.</subfield><subfield code="2">aat</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="700" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="i">Based on (work)</subfield><subfield code="a">Tiepolo, Giovanni Domenico,</subfield><subfield code="d">1726?-1804.</subfield><subfield code="t">Scène Carnival, le menuet.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="700" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Tiepolo, Giovanni Domenico,</subfield><subfield code="d">1726?-1804,</subfield><subfield code="e">artist.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="993" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">770000000066 </subfield><subfield code="n">Mary Ann O'Brian Malkin Program Endowment for Rare Books and Manuscripts</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="949" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">RBM 9585 MP/MC/R/20.15</subfield><subfield code="w">ASIS</subfield><subfield code="c">1</subfield><subfield code="i">000076921179</subfield><subfield code="l">SPC-MAPPHO</subfield><subfield code="m">UP-SPECCOL</subfield><subfield code="r">Y</subfield><subfield code="s">Y</subfield><subfield code="t">ARCHIVES</subfield><subfield code="u">11/1/2013</subfield></datafield></record>
all_text_timv: Leonardis, Jacopo, 1723-approximately 1782, engraver. Vario è il vestir, ma il desiderio è un solo Cercan tutti fuggir tristezza, e duolo / Tiepolo inv. e depin. ; l'originale e posseduto dal Cante Algarotti in Vena. ; Giac. Leonardis delin. e inc. 1765. In Venezia : appo. Giacomo Leonardis, [1765] 1 print ; 33 x 47 cm still image sti rdacontent unmediated n rdamedia sheet nb rdacarrier In Rare Books and Manuscripts, University Libraries, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA (#(RBM 9585.) "No. 10." Collection is open for research. The collection consists of one mezzotint print, taken from a 1765 engraving by Jacopo Leonardis, based on the original oil painting Scène Carnival, or, Le menuet, painted in 1750 by Giovanni Domenico Tiepolo. Purchased with funds from the  Mary Ann O'Brian Malkin Program Endowment for Rare Books and Manuscripts; 2013 Giovanni Domenico Tiepolo was an Italian painter and printmaker. Born in Venice, he studied art with his father, famed Rococco artist Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, and by age 20 was accepting his own commissions. As he moved from Wurzburg to Vicenza to Madrid, his style evolved, and while he retained the decorative technique of his father he gradually incorporated a more mature, realistic approach into his paintings. Representative of his early work is the 1750 painting Scène Carnival, or, Le menuet, which combines his father's ornate, brightly colored Rococco influence with the realistic scene of performers dancing at a carnival. Originally attributed to his father, the painting was part of the collection of the Venetian polymath, Count Francesco Algarotti, and  is currently in the Louvre. Giacomo  Leonardis was an Italian engraver. Born in Palmanova, Venice Republic, he studied under Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, and made popular etchings of Italian paintings. Dance Early works to 1800 Pictorial works. Carnivals Early works to 1800 Pictorial works. Prints. aat Based on (work) Tiepolo, Giovanni Domenico, 1726?-1804. Scène Carnival, le menuet. Tiepolo, Giovanni Domenico, 1726?-1804, artist.

administrative_history_note_ssm: Giovanni Domenico Tiepolo was an Italian painter and printmaker. Born in Venice, he studied art with his father, famed Rococco artist Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, and by age 20 was accepting his own commissions. As he moved from Wurzburg to Vicenza to Madrid, his style evolved, and while he retained the decorative technique of his father he gradually incorporated a more mature, realistic approach into his paintings. Representative of his early work is the 1750 painting Scène Carnival, or, Le menuet, which combines his father's ornate, brightly colored Rococco influence with the realistic scene of performers dancing at a carnival. Originally attributed to his father, the painting was part of the collection of the Venetian polymath, Count Francesco Algarotti, and  is currently in the Louvre.
Giacomo  Leonardis was an Italian engraver. Born in Palmanova, Venice Republic, he studied under Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, and made popular etchings of Italian paintings.
